entry.title: [CW] Today marks four years since Richard Russell stole a plane from SeaTac airport,
entry.content:
Today marks four years since Richard Russell stole a plane from SeaTac airport, did a barrel roll, then crashed into a remote island. RIP Skyking.
This story has always held my attention, and I must admit to a certain amount of wistful fascination with the entire episode. The story of a nobody who does something extraordinary, even though it meant his death. There's something glorious about it. Despite the need to avoid glorifying a man stealing an airplane to take it on a joyride, I can't help but admire him.
There aren't many other things I can think of that are simultaneously ill-advised and wonderfully glorious. The one that came to mind, that has a similar feeling to me, is Alex Honnold, the man who freeclimbed El Capitan. Like stealing an airplane, freeclimbing El Capitan is ill-advised, and yet undeniably glorious. Obviously Alex didn't have to steal anything, and Alex didn't die doing it. Alex planned, and didn't break any laws. But still. The feeling I get from both resonate, harmonize. Maybe it's close to the admiration I have for Ted Kaczynski, who more than all else lived his morals and implemented them as he saw fit. Of course, while Alex didn't kill anyone and didn't die, and Richard didn't kill anyone but himself, Ted killed other people, and is still alive (for now). Ted's not glorious, not like Alex, not like Richard, even. Maybe I'm just a sucker for iconoclasts, and don't have the moral fortitude to decry their transgressions. Maybe I'm just confused.
I don't really have a point with this post, other than to mark the anniversary of Richard's flight. I'd be curious to know if this story affected anyone here like it did me, if anyone can recognize the kind of wistfulness I feel, and if there are any other people or stories who make them feel the same way. Maybe there's a German word that describes it, one I don't know.
